2.text: But Oddly, one of the hardest things to do is not hold it against people

7.text: When they do actually turn around and reciprocate our feelings.

11.text: It can be immensely hard not to think that those who offer us love

15.text: Are in some ways weak, mistaken, needy, craven or just defective

22.text: It can feel a lot easier when love was unrequited

26.text: when our primary preoccupation was a thrilling dread

30.text: that the admired person hadn't even noticed us

33.text: But now there's finally no doubt anymore

35.text: It's really clear they do like us and something troubling has arisen

43.text: We're tempted to say we got them wrong.  They can't be the admirable people we thought they were

48.text: But the issue isn't really to do with them at all

57.text: Their affection seem suspicious, incomprehensible and a touch repulsive

62.text: because at some level this isn't what we're used to. it doesn't tally with our view of ourselves.

68.text: Love can be hard to receive when we're not fundamentally convinced of our own lovability.

74.text: We spend our time seeking out those who can make us suffer in ways that feel familiar.

80.text: And it becomes natural to assume that a kind lover has missed something

84.text: And perhaps then, to try to behave in disgusting ways just to make sure they understand

89.text: We're really not who they thought we were.

92.text: And that they would therefore leave us in painful but somehow psychologically gratifying ways

97.text: in short, how could anyone be so great if they have the bad taste to think well of someone like us?

105.text: but we have to allow ourselves to entertain another option

109.text: perhaps this affection we're receiving is not a sign that our kind lover is weak or wrong or has no other options

117.text: perhaps it's a sign that they've seen something in us

120.text: which pointedly and tragically we don't yet quite see in ourselves

125.text: and have never been alowed to believe in by figures in our past

128.text: that we are deserving of love.

132.text: there is hope in all this

134.text: Hope that we can come to trust our lovers more that we trust our own first nervous, self-destructive impulses

141.text: We can interpret their love, not as a sign of their delusion or weakness,

146.text: but as evidence of an inherent lovability in ourselves

149.text: to which our past histories have blinded us

152.text: yet to which their love and tenderness can now awaken us
